problems: No serious problems.
notes: Not preferred by deer. Understory tree with four season interest.

problems: Susceptible to minor leaf infections and golden stem canker.
notes: Used by 64 wildlife species, 43 bird species. Prefers slightly acidic soil. Best in part shade, protected from wind. Four season interest.

problems: Beech bark disease is major problem.
notes: Best in moderate to slightly acid soils.  Due to beech bark disease, may need to plant only disease resistant seedlings if available.

problems: Chestnut blight has nearly eliminated this species.
notes: There are breeding programs working on blight resistant hybrids. Planting non-resistant trees is not recommended. Visit https://www.acf.org/ for more info.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Excessively Drained - Moderately Well Drained
problems: Highly susceptible to diseases and insects.  Apple scab, cedar apple rust, fireblight, mildew, borer, scale, Japanese beetle. Plant at least 500 feet from cedars.
notes: Preferred by deer. Adaptable to most soil conditions but does best in full sun in moist, well-drained soil.

problems: Dutch elm disease has eliminated most of these trees from the landscape.
notes: There are breeding programs working on blight resistant hybrids. Planting non-resistant trees is not recommended.

problems: Japanese beetles, scale insects, filbert blight.
notes: Thicket forming. Tolerates a wide range of conditions but does best in full sun.

problems: Minor leaf spots.
notes: Tolerates a wide range of soil conditions.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Poorly Drained - Very Poorly Drained
problems: Disease problems are not common. Larch case-bearer, larch sawfly.
notes: Larch is a deciduous conifer. It loses its needles every year. Shallow root system makes it susceptible to wind throw.

problems: Bacterial fireblight can be a severe problem. Scab, cankers, crown gall, powdery mildew, rust. Borers, aphids, sawfly, scale.
notes: Requires moist, rich, acidic, well-drained soils in full sun but tolerates partial shade.  Short lived due to diseases and pests.

problems: Anthracnose, leafspots, aphids, plant bug, scales, bagworm, borers.
notes: Not preferred by deer. Showy bark. Has a vigorous root system that can invade sewer pipes, drainage systems, etc. Adapts to a range of soil pH. Excellent riparian species.

problems: Susceptible to many disease and insects, including black knot, mildew, rust, root rots, fireblight, borers, mites, tent caterpillars.
notes: Preferred by deer. Utilized by many species of wildlife and birds.

problems: No common problems but cankers and woolly aphids can occur.
notes: Does best in cold climates. Prefers well drained, acidic soil.

problems: Aphids, Japanese beetles, linden borer. Anthracnose, verticillium wilt.
notes: Adaptable to alkaline soils.

problems: Oak wilt. Can suffer chlorosis due to absence of soil nutrients.
notes: Small, shrubby species of oak that thrives in dry, rocky, sandy mountainous terrain.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Excessively Drained - Moderately Well Drained
problems: Susceptible to many disease and insects.
notes: Will grow in nearly any soil condition (extreme wet being an exception).  Reproduces rapidly. Excellent early successional species.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Prefers deep, moist well-drained soils, but is often found in drier conditions.

problems: Aphids, canker, leaf miner, birch skeletonizer may occur. Watch for leaf spot problems.
notes: Prefers moist sites but tolerates dry. Colonizes open or disturbed areas.

problems: Black knot is very common. Eastern tent caterpillar is common.
notes: Not preferred by deer or voles. Prefers dry, upland sites.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: A very dependable species. Prefers moist acidic soil but tolerates a wide variety of conditions.

problems: Cankers, leaf spots. Can develop chlorotic (yellowing) leaves in high pH soils.
notes: Not preferred by deer. Prefers moist, well-drained, acidic soils high in organic matter. Does best in full sun.

problems: Some insect and disease problems but severity unknown.
notes: Prefers sandy or rocky soils in sun to partial shade.

problems: Locust borer.
notes: Not preferred by deer or voles. Grows in a wide range of conditions but wet sites should be avoided.

problems: Scale, two-lined chestnut borer. Oak wilt, galls.
notes: Well suited to adapt to climate change.

problems: Mildew, rusts.
notes: Thicket forming. Best in neutral to lightly acidic soils in full sun to part shade.

problems: Thousand canker disease is a serious problem. Walnut and yellow leaf caterpillars. Anthracnose.
notes: May be county limitations due to Thousand canker disease. May not be recommended for planting. Refer to local county authorities. Produces a chemical, juglone,  which is toxic to many plants.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Poorly Drained - Very Poorly Drained
problems: Cankers.
notes: Excellent streambank stabilizer. Has a vigorous root system that can invade sewer pipes, drainage systems, etc. Excellent riparian species.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Adaptable to most sites, wet, dry, sun, or shade.

problems: Hosts box elder bugs.
notes: Do not plant near homes or buildings because box elder bugs will infest structure. Thicket forming.

problems: Oak wilt. Anthracnose, bacterial leaf scorch, and powdery mildew. Galls, scale.
notes: Tolerant of many soil conditions.

problems: Butternut canker is a serious problem.
notes: May be county limitations due to Butternut canker.  Not recommended for planting. Refer to local county authorities. Produces a chemical, juglone, which is toxic to many plants.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Attracts over 24 species of birds and numerous butterflies. Plant only in sunny, wet sites.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Not preferred by deer. Thicket forming. Does good in wet sites.

problems: Scale, two-lined chestnut borer. Oak wilt, galls.
notes: Tolerates most soils except those that drain poorly.

problems: Susceptible to many disease and insects. Black knot, mildew, rust, root rots, fireblight, borers, mites, tent caterpillars.
notes: Often forms a dense colony.

problems: Very prone to disease. Cedar rust diseases, fireblight, leaf spots, scale, mites.
notes: Caution: This species has long, sharp dangerous thorns.

problems: Very few disease and insect problems.  Scale insects can attack occasionally. Leaves may scorch during summer in dry sites.
notes: Does well in both full sun and partial shade.  Does not do well in windy or polluted sites. Showy flowers and fruit.

problems: Rust and leaf spots are occasional problems.
notes: Used by 58 wildlife species, 35 bird species. Understory tree with four season interest.

problems: Woolly adelgid has severely harmed and killed this species in most areas of PA. Hemlock scale, bagworm, needle rust mite, needle blight.
notes: PA State Tree. Shelter from strong winter winds to avoid winter burn.

problems: Cedar rusts (cedar-apple, cedar-hawthorn and cedar-quince) and bagworm are common.
notes: Berries consumed by over 50 species of birds. Tolerant of dry, windy conditions once established. Does well in alkaline soils.

problems: Susceptible to borers, cankers, verticillium wilt.
notes: Fixes nitrogen. Suffers in full sun or extreme heat.  Can also be frost/cold sensitive.

problems: White pine decline, white pine blister rust. Chlorosis in high pH soils.
notes: Preferred by deer. Cold tolerant. Intolerant of wet or clay soils. Avoid planting in open, windy sites. Young trees tolerate light shade.

problems: Leaf spots, cankers, borers, powdery mildew, spider mites, aphids.
notes: Tolerant of soil pH.  Can sucker to form colonies.

problems: Susceptible to insect and disease problems. Anthracnose.
notes: Do not plant in heavy clay soil. Does best sheltered from wind. Prefers acidic soil.

problems: Resistant to bronze birch borer and air pollution. Leaf miners and cankers are possible. Chlorosis may occur in high pH soils.
notes: A good species for poor soil and tough sites.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Tolerates a wide range of conditions.

problems: Heavy aerial salt can cause witch’s broom and hackberry nipple gall.
notes: Common on limestone soils but tolerates a range of pH. Tolerant of many soil and weather conditions.

problems: Chlorosis in high pH soils. Stem cankers, virus, plum curculio.
notes: Sometimes requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production. Performs well in wet sites.

problems: Viburnum leaf beetle.
notes: Grows best in moist, well-drained, humusy soil. Does well in wet conditions.

problems: A wide range of diseases and pests can affect this tree: honeylocust plant bug, spider mites, leaf spots, canker.
notes: Caution: This species has long, sharp dangerous thorns. Consider planting other species.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: A tough species with few problems.  Occurs naturally in dry woodland understory. Perfoms best in slightly acid soil that is moist, fertile and  well-drained.

problems: Aphids, scale, borers.
notes: Four season interest. Tolerant of soil pH.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Does best in slightly acidic soil.

problems: Leaf spots, blights. Borers, scale, white fly, lace bugs.
notes: PA State Flower. Does best in cool, moist, rich, acidic, humusy, well-drained soils in part shade.

problems: Viburnum crown borer.
notes: Very adaptable from full sun to shade, in dry sites to moist, wet sites.

problems: Leaf spots, powdery mildew, cankers.
notes: A very tough species that is tolerant of a very wide range of conditions.

problems: No serious problems. Chlorosis in high pH soils.
notes: Requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production.  Does best in slightly acidic, moist soil.

problems: Chlorosis in high pH soils.  Oak wilt, galls.
notes: Prefers well drained, rich woodland sites.

problems: Somewhat susceptible to bronze birch borer. Aphids, leaf miner, birch skeletonizer may occur. Watch for leaf spot problems.
notes: Prefers moist, acidic, sandy or rocky, well-drained soils, but will tolerate a range of soil types.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Difficult to predict fruit production because they are trioecious (subdioecious), which means they have separate male, female as well as hermaphroditic plants.  May require two clones to produce fruit.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production. Tolerant of wide range of soil moisture and pH levels.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Adaptable to sandy or clay loams in well-drained soils in sun to partial sun.

problems: Susceptible to fireblight, canker, borer.
notes: Thicket forming. Does best in cool climates in full sun.

problems: Chlorosis can cause serious damage in high pH soils. Galls, oak wilt, oak blister.
notes: Prefers wet, acidic soil.

problems: Susceptible to diseases and pest that are common in pines.
notes: Many birds feed on the seeds. Best in areas with full sun.  Pefers moist, well-drained soil but will tolerate a wide range of soils including poor, dry and rocky soil.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Prefers sun to part shade in acidic, moist, well-drained soils but can be adaptable.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Poorly Drained - Very Poorly Drained
problems: Mildew, blights, leaf spots, cankers, borer, aphids.
notes: Requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Excessively Drained - Moderately Well Drained
problems: Numerous disease and pest problems if not sited correctly.
notes: Prefers cool summer climates.  Does not tolerate summer heat or pollution. Requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production.  Excellent early successional species.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Excessively Drained - Moderately Well Drained
problems: Dutch elm disease has eliminated most of these trees from the landscape.
notes: There are breeding programs working on blight resistant hybrids. Planting non-resistant trees is not recommended.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: A very dependable species. Prefers moist soil but tolerates a wide range of conditions.

problems: Verticillium wilt, maple bladder gall, leaf hoppers. Chlorosis can be a problem in high pH soil and drought conditions.
notes: Very common tree in PA.

problems: A variety of pests are possible including leaf spots, witch's brooms, cankers, powdery mildew, spider mites, scale insects.
notes: Requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production.

problems: Susceptible to many insect and disease problems.
notes: Prefers a dry, loose, sandy soil with a low pH in full sun. Adapted to extremely cold climates.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Excessively Drained - Somewhat Poorly Drained
problems: Spruce budworm, eastern spruce beetle, European spruce sawfly, yellow-headed spruce sawfly.
notes: It is a cool region tree that requires full sun, ample moisture, and acidic, well-drained soil, even being able to grow on rocky soil but also cool swamps and bogs.  Typically found at high elevations.

problems: Stem canker is common on this species. Leaf spots.
notes: Four season interest. Tolerates a wide range of conditions but does best in full sun and moist/wet conditions.

problems: Resistant to bronze birch borer. Susceptible to aphids, leaf miners, leaf spots. Iron chlorosis is common in high pH soils.
notes: Not preferred by deer.

problems: Cankers and possibly others.
notes: Excellent streambank stabilizer.

problems: Laurel wilt, Japanese beetle, powdery mildew, leaf spots, cankers.
notes: Requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production.

problems: Oak wilt, scale, two-lined chestnut borer, galls.
notes: Prefers dry, upland sites.

uses: Edible nut, use bark for syrup
problems: No serious problems.
notes: Attractive peeling bark used by bats.

problems: Scale, leaf spots, stem cankers.
notes: Four season interest. Best in full sun in moist areas. Tolerant of soil pH.

problems: Scale, leaf spots, stem cankers.
notes: Four season interest. Tolerant of soil pH. Excellent riparian species.

problems: Verticillium wilt (fungus), anthracnose, tar spot, cottony maple scale, maple bladder gall.
notes: Has a vigorous root system that can invade sewer pipes, drainage systems, etc.

problems: Canker, powdery mildew, leaf curl. Aphids, leaf miners, tent caterpillars, lace bugs, flea beetles. Chlorosis will occur in high pH soils.
notes: Commonly mistaken for Alnus glutinosa, a highly invasive species. Use caution and ensure that the planting stock is not European balck alder (Alnus glutinosa).

problems: Cankers, leaf spots, powdery mildew, verticillium wilt, rusts.
notes: Requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production. Can form large colonies by suckering.  Adapts to many soil conditions.

problems: Powdery mildew, leaf spots, viburnum leaf beetle, verticillium wilt. Fairly resistant to viburnum crown borer.
notes: Dense, multi-stemmed and hardy.

problems: Potential problems include cankers, alder aphids, Japanese beetles, leaf miners.
notes: Commonly mistaken for Alnus glutinosa, a highly invasive species. Use caution and ensure that the planting stock is not European balck alder (Alnus glutinosa).

problems: Generally disease free but laurel wilt can be a problem.
notes: Female plants procude berries that are high in fat content are are highly sought by many bird species. Requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production.

problems: Leaf spots, rust, verticillium wilt.
notes: Requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production. Can form large colonies by suckering.  Adapts to many soil conditions except wet sites.

problems: Susceptible to leaf scorch, verticillium wilt, tar spot and anthracnose. Pests include borers and cottony maple scale.
notes: Prime producer of sap for maple syrup.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Poorly Drained - Very Poorly Drained
problems: Anthracnose, occasional powdery mildew, chlorois in high pH soils, insect galls, oak wilt.
notes: Tolerant of many soil conditions but it is best to avoid high pH.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Poorly Drained - Very Poorly Drained
problems: Chlorosis can occur in alkaline soils.
notes: Requires acidic soil. Not winter hardy in most of PA.

problems: Chlorosis can be a problem in high pH soils
notes: Trees produce spiky gumball fruits--use caution when choosing planting location.  Marginally hardy. Southeast PA only.

soilDrainage: Somewhat Excessively Drained - Moderately Well Drained
problems: No serious problems.
notes: Very fragrant. Exceptional pollinator value. Spreads by suckering roots forming wide colonies. Tolerant of soil ph.

problems: Some insect and disease problems but severity unknown.
notes: Grows in wooded areas and next to bogs and swamps. Grows in acidic soils that are low in nutrients.

problems: Aphids, scales, mildew, canker, verticillium wilt are possible problems.
notes: Preferred by deer. Prefers moist, well-drained, slightly acidic soils but is tolerant of more alkaline soil. Showy flowers.

problems: Pitch canker. Susceptible to diseases and pest that are common in pines.
notes: Many birds feed on the seeds. Does best in sites with full sun, well-drained soil, and sandy acidic loam. Will grow in poor, dry soils, including clay soils.

problems: Oak wilt, anthracnose, two-lined chestnut borer, galls, scale.
notes: Does best in well drained soil.

soilDrainage: Moderately Well Drained - Very Poorly Drained
problems: No serious problems. Chlorosis can occur in alkaline soils.
notes: The bright red fruitson females plants persist in the winter landscape.  Requires male and female plants for fruit/seed production.

problems: No serious problems.
notes: Yellow flowers bloom in October and often persist into winter.

problems: Resistant to bronze birch borer and leaf miner. Stem canker, aphids, birch skeletonizer may occur. Watch for leaf spot problems.
notes: Prefers cool, moist conditions. Common on calcareous soils.
